front.title: Tagged JavaScript Object Notation (TJSON) Data Interchange Format

abstract.t: Tagged JavaScript Object Notation (TJSON) is a data interchange format which is backwards compatible with the JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) format. It adds first-class type annotations ("tags") for supporting a richer set of types within JSON documents.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Tagged JavaScript Object Notation (TJSON) is a set of backwards-compatible extensions to JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) which enrich the set of types the format is able to express.
TJSON can represent six primitive types (strings, binary data, integers, floating points, datetimes, and null) and two structured types (objects and arrays).

To extend JSON with additional types in a backwards-compatible manner, TJSON adds a special mandatory "tag" to each JSON string which identifies the data type and, optionally, encoding format. A tag consists of one or more alphanumeric characters, followed by the colon ":" character. All strings in TJSON MUST have a valid tag prefix.

TJSON is intended to simplify transcoding documents from other interchange formats which disambiguate strings from binary data, and also improve the ability to both canonicalize and authenticate JSON documents.

section.title: TJSON Grammar
section.t: TJSON relies on JSON as the basis of its grammar. All TJSON documents are valid JSON documents (however the reverse is not true). The TJSON grammar can thus be seen as an extension of the JSON grammar, but one implemented in a backwards-compatible way.

section.t: The following section describes the extended types added to TJSON by embedding them in string literals as described in section 2.1 of this document.

section.title: Binary Data
section.t: TJSON provides first-class support for binary data stored in multiple different encodings within a tagged string. Tags for binary data begin with the "b" character followed by an alphanumeric identifier for a specific format.
The preferred encoding is base64url ("b64:"), which SHOULD be used by default unless another encoding is explicitly specified at serialization time.
The base16 and base64url formats are mandatory to implement for all TJSON parsers.

section.title: base16 ("b16:")
section.t: A base16 literal starts with the "b16:" tag, followed by a valid base16 string. The base16 format (a.k.a. hexadecimal) is described in . All base16 strings in TJSON MUST be lower case.

section.title: base64url ("b64:")
section.t: A base64url literal starts with the "b64:" tag, followed by a valid base64url string. The base64url format is described in . All base64url strings in TJSON MUST NOT include any padding with the '=' character. TJSON parsers MUST reject any documents containing padded base64url strings.
The following is an example of a base64url string literal in TJSON:
This should decode to the equivalent of the ASCII string: "Hello, world!"
Only the base64url format is supported. The non-URL safe form of base64 is not supported and MUST be rejected by parsers.

section.title: Integers ("i:")
section.t: TJSON provides a standard syntax for representing integers as tagged strings, which allows representing more than the [-(2**53)+1, (2**53)-1] range of integers defined as interoperable in .
An integer literal tagged string starts with the "i:" tag, followed by a valid JSON integer literal, with an optional minus character.
Conforming TJSON parsers MUST be capable of supporting the full integer range [−(2**63), (2**63)−1], i.e. the range of a signed 64-bit integer.
Integers outside this range MUST be rejected.

section.title: Floating Points
section.t: All numeric literals which are not represented as tagged strings MUST be treated as floating points under TJSON. This is already the default behavior of many JSON libraries.
